conclusion: Determine the maximum horizontal force F that can be applied to block B without causing block A and B to move relative to each other.
Block A is on top of block B, and a horizontal force F is applied to block B.
Mass of A is 1 kg, maximum static friction force is 1 N.
The maximum static friction force provides the maximum acceleration that block A can have: a_max = 1 m/s².
Mass of B is 2 kg, coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.1, acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s².
The friction force between block B and the ground is 3 N.
Net force acting on the system (A + B) is F - f_k = (m_A + m_B) * a.
For maximum acceleration a = a_max = 1 m/s², F - 3 N = 3 N, so F = 6 N.
The horizontal force F must not exceed 6 N to keep blocks A and B moving together without relative motion.
